ROBERT FIELD: I'm Bob Field.
I'm in the Chemistry Department.

I've been in the Chemistry
Department for 35 years.

The course is
Molecular Spectroscopy,

which used to be called
576 Molecular Spectroscopy.

And it's now, the most
recent incarnation, 580.

The course 580 starts
with some crucial ideas

about the electronic
structure of atoms

and then develops from there
to the electronic structure

and other things that
molecules can do.

It's mostly taken by
graduate students.

However, there have always
been one or two undergraduate
students taking this course.

And they've always
entered graduate school

with a tremendous
advantage over the others,

in the sense that they
understand how spectroscopy
works and how molecules work.

And spectroscopy is
applied quantum mechanics.

And so a student who has not
had a fair amount of experience

with quantum mechanics
will be very much
out of place in this course.

Although, I also have
a relatively simple way

of approaching
quantum mechanics,

that even if a
student has not had

a course in matrix formulation
of quantum mechanics,
they will soon get the idea.

It's a course that captures my
vision of how molecules work.

And it's a very unconventional
course not found

in any textbook
except my own, which
is the book on small molecules.

It's called The Spectra and
Dynamics of Diatomic Molecules.

My aim in teaching 576 is to
show that spectroscopy is not

just energy levels
and formulas, but it's

a way of understanding
how molecules work.

And basically, the insistence
on things being simple,

as opposed to
multi-digit complicated,
is what I'm trying to get at.

Well, it's a fairly
old-fashioned lecture course.

It's based on printed
lecture notes that
have evolved over the years.

Every time I give this course,
I go deeper into the subject.

So if someone from
outside of MIT

were to approach this course
and want to learn from it,

I would recommend that
that person decide

on which of the many topics
covered in the lecture syllabus

they're interested
and pick a few of them

and study them rather than
to read the whole material.

But my goal is to
present simple pictures,

simple and memorable
names for things,

and just to have a sense that
molecules are their friends

and have few surprises
that they can't anticipate.
I love teaching.
I love sharing my ideas.

And it's a wonderful
thing to be asked

to learn something well enough
to explain it to other people.

And I regard this
course as the one

where the learning
was most intense,

and the conveying of
that was most rewarding.
